prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
Receiver: Band 7 (spectral line CO (3-2), plus continuum) Our primary goal is to map the distribution and kinematics of CO (3-2), however we also include contunuum to maximize science output.
Angular Resolution: 0.15'' at Band 7 in order to match the scales probed by adaptive optics-assisted near-infrared IFU spectroscopy and enable a direct comparison of the cold and warm molecular gas.
Spectral Resolution: Total bandwidth of 4X2000 MHz and a resolution of 31.25 MHz. This will give us a resolution of ~28km/s and will allow us to reach our desired sensitivity.
Band 7 sensitivity: The sensitivity is calculated from SMA CO(3-2) measurements (Wilson 2008 and personal data). The SMA observations have a beam size of 1-2 arcsec. Since we wish to resolve faint outflows, we make the conservative estimate that the observed flux is evenly distributed over the SMA beam. Our sources have line widths of around 700 km/s. While the peak flux of the lines are around 12mJy /(0.15'' beam), the outflows detected in the wings of the CO line are ~ 3.5- 4 mJy /(0.15''beam). We therefore require a sensitivity of 0.8 to achieve the desired 5 sigma detection.
Band 7 Observing time: For Band 6 and assuming thirty-four 12m antennas and dual polarization, the ALMA sensitivity calculator predicts ~4.4 hours total integration to reach 5 sigma in the channel for each target. The time on source is 27.83, 20.09, 18.53, 24.08 minutes for each target (IRASF22491,III Zw 35, IRAS 17207, IRAS 01364). The total time requested per target is 1.28, 1.05, 0.96,1.12 hours respectively. Our overheads are ~25% of the total time requsted, which is within the limit (<30%) suggested.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal performs a pilot study of CO molecular gas in the nuclear region of four local gas-rich galaxy mergers whose infrared properties identify them as likely candidates of small-scale outflows. The proposed ALMA CO(3-2) observations at ∼0.1” resolution will match the scales probed by adaptive optics-assisted near-infrared integral field spectroscopy, enabling a direct comparison of the cold and warm molecular gas for the first time. A comparison of the CO with outflowing H2 gas detected in these galaxies will reveal the structure of cold gas entrained in the high-velocity winds and advance our understanding of how outflows couple to the cold molecular gas.
